DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against all major foreign currencies today in lackluster pre-holiday European trading. Gold prices were up slightly in thin dealings. Traders said many market players already have left for extended holiday vacations. ``It's absolutely dead today,'' said a trader at a large commercial bank in Frankfurt. ``There's nothing going on. People are just sitting around their offices waiting for quitting time.'' In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.10 yen to a closing 143.67 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 143.45 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Thursday: _1.7145 West German marks, down from 1.7250 _1.5523 Swiss francs, down from 1.5575 _5.8530 French francs, down from 5.8955 _1.9435 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9560 _1,281.50 Italian lire, down from 1,287.50 _1.1598 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1605 In London, the dollar fell against the British pound. It cost $1.6165 to buy one pound, compared with $1.6125 late Thursday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $413.00 a troy ounce, up from $412.75 bid late Thursday. At midmorning, the city's five major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $413.20. In Zurich, the bid price was $413.00, unchanged from the bid late Thursday. Gold in Hong Kong rose 33 cents to close at a bid $411.69. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $5.59 a troy ounce, up from Thursday's $5.57.
